channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The U.S. ready to make up, Europe ready to break up in Munich
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio tried to reassure Europe at the Munich Security Conference, but European leaders are skeptical.
item.content:encoded:
Secretary of State Marco Rubio tried to reassure Europe at the Munich Security Conference, but European leaders are skeptical.

(Image credit: Johannes Simon)
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: DHS shuts down after a funding lapse. And, why athletes get the 'yips' at the Olympics
item.description: Congress is out on recess as a partial shutdown at the Department of Homeland Security is underway. And, why some superstar athletes have been getting the "yips" at the Winter Olympics in Italy.
item.content:encoded:
Congress is out on recess as a partial shutdown at the Department of Homeland Security is underway. And, why some superstar athletes have been getting the "yips" at the Winter Olympics in Italy.

(Image credit: Alex Wong)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Israel will begin contentious West Bank land registration
item.description: Israel will begin a contentious land regulation process in a large part of the occupied West Bank, which could result in Israel gaining control over wide swaths of the area for future development.
item.content:encoded:
Israel will begin a contentious land regulation process in a large part of the occupied West Bank, which could result in Israel gaining control over wide swaths of the area for future development.

(Image credit: Ohad Zwigenberg)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: An Islamist party becomes Bangladesh's main opposition for the first time
item.description: An Islamist party has become Bangladesh's main opposition for the first time in the country's history, challenging the old dynastic political system despite persistent concerns among critics about the party's policies on women.
item.content:encoded:
An Islamist party has become Bangladesh's main opposition for the first time in the country's history, challenging the old dynastic political system despite persistent concerns among critics about the party's policies on women.

(Image credit: Sajjad Hussain)
item.dc:creator: Shamim Chowdhury

item.title: Russia, Ukraine and US officials to meet this week for more talks to end the war
item.description: As the war in Ukraine nears its fourth anniversary, officials from Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. will meet in Geneva Tuesday for another round of talks aimed at ending the war.
item.content:encoded: As the war in Ukraine nears its fourth anniversary, officials from Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. will meet in Geneva Tuesday for another round of talks aimed at ending the war.
item.dc:creator: Charles Maynes

item.title: World leaders met in Munich to discuss the future of Europe. Here's what happened
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel asks Kurt Volker, a former U.S. ambassador to NATO, for his takeaways following this year's Munich Security Conference.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel asks Kurt Volker, a former U.S. ambassador to NATO, for his takeaways following this year's Munich Security Conference.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: With no Gaza disarmament deal, UN group hasn't begun major work to clear explosives
item.description: The United Nations group that clears explosives from conflict zones tells NPR it has not started major clearing operations in Gaza, because Israel and Hamas have not yet agreed on the terms for disarmament of the territory.
item.content:encoded: The United Nations group that clears explosives from conflict zones tells NPR it has not started major clearing operations in Gaza, because Israel and Hamas have not yet agreed on the terms for disarmament of the territory.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: US and Iran head to Geneva to continue talks on Iran's nuclear program. What to know
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Vali Nasr, a professor of Middle East studies at Johns Hopkins University, about nuclear negotiations between the U.S. and Iran.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Vali Nasr, a professor of Middle East studies at Johns Hopkins University, about nuclear negotiations between the U.S. and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: As US presence wanes, China works to increase its influence through foreign aid
item.description: When the U.S. pulled back on giving out foreign aid last year, fears emerged that China would swoop to take America's place. But China's approach may signify a different role for it in global health.
item.content:encoded: When the U.S. pulled back on giving out foreign aid last year, fears emerged that China would swoop to take America's place. But China's approach may signify a different role for it in global health.
item.dc:creator: Fatma Tanis

item.title: North Korea opens a housing district for families of its soldiers killed in Russia-Ukraine war
item.description: North Korea said Monday it completed a new housing district in Pyongyang for families of North Korean soldiers killed while fighting alongside Russian forces in Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
North Korea said Monday it completed a new housing district in Pyongyang for families of North Korean soldiers killed while fighting alongside Russian forces in Ukraine.

(Image credit: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
